page.title: 01INTRODUCTION
page.content:
This area, south of the Town of{ {Winchcombe,}is drained by Beesmoor Brook, Langley Brook and the River Isbourne. The land rises southward away from the centre of a natural bowl in which{Winchcombe}is situated.
As the land rises, geologists tell us that it is made up of Middle Lias and Upper Lias clays moving towards the Inferior Oolite at Belas Knap. Springs emerge at the junction of the Upper Lias and the limestone; deep valleys have been cut by the R.Isbourne; ponds are formed where the underground water is high.(eg.Washpool)
The oolitic limestone makes a superb building material, being quarried in the past around the Corndean area. It is this stone that gives buildings in this area their warm glowing tints.
